blogs.title: Kenyan Political Giant Raila Odinga Dies at 80 in India
blogs.body:
Former Kenyan Prime Minister and veteran opposition leader Raila Amolo Odinga has died at the age of 80 after suffering a cardiac arrest while undergoing treatment in India. Odinga, a towering figure in Kenyan and African politics for decades, collapsed during a morning walk at an Ayurvedic treatment facility in Koothattukulam, Kerala, on Wednesday morning. His death creates an immediate and profound leadership vacuum in Kenya's political opposition.

Indian media reported that medical staff rushed Odinga to Devamatha Hospital in the nearby Ernakulam district, but doctors pronounced him dead shortly after 9:50 a.m. local time. Hospital sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the cardiac event to news agencies, noting resuscitation efforts failed. Odinga had been in India for specialized Ayurvedic treatment, a facility his daughter had previously visited for her vision. The Kenyan Embassy in Delhi is coordinating efforts for the repatriation of his body.

Odinga's nearly five-decade career defined modern Kenyan democracy. Born in 1945, the son of Kenya's first Vice-President, he courageously endured years of detention without trial under the single-party regime of Daniel arap Moi for his pro-democracy activism. He served as the Prime Minister of Kenya from 2008 to 2013 in a power-sharing arrangement that ended post-election violence.Despite running for the presidency unsuccessfully five times—most recently in 2022—he remained a hugely influential leader, consistently demanding electoral justice and constitutional reform.

Leaders across the globe immediately expressed shock and grief at the news. Kenyan President William Ruto led the nation in mourning, while former Chief Justice David Maraga called Odinga a "patriot, a pan-Africanist, a democrat and a leader who made significant contributions to democracy in Kenya and in Africa," posting his sentiments on X.Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi described Odinga as a "towering statesman" and a "cherished friend of India."

Odinga’s passing leaves the Azimio la Umoja One Kenya Coalition Party without its unifying force ahead of the 2027 general elections. Known affectionately by supporters as "Baba," his populist rallies mobilized masses, demonstrating his powerful connection to ordinary Kenyans. "Kenya has lost one of its most formidable leaders who shaped the trajectory of our beloved country," Maraga added. Political analysts suggest Odinga’s death will trigger a rapid realignment of political forces, challenging the stability of the current political landscape and the recent truce he struck with the government.

blogs.title: Jesus Fails to Return
blogs.body:
The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness, led by popular televangelist Prophet David Owuor, has dismissed claims circulating on social media suggesting that the world would end on Saturday, August 2, 2025.

In a strongly worded statement, the church described the doomsday predictions linked to the church and it’s founder as false, baseless, and malicious. The church asserts that the statements were deliberately crafted to tarnish the reputation of both Prophet Owuor and the ministry.

The statement, signed by Senior Archbishop Michael Nieswand, emphasized that the Bible is clear on matters concerning the end of the world, citing Matthew 24:36, which states that “no one knows the day or hour when the Messiah will return.”

“We, the leadership and congregation of the Ministry of Repentance and Holiness, strongly denounce the recent spread of false and misleading information about the world ending on August 2, 2025,” the statement read.
“These claims are false, baseless, malicious, and intended to harm not only the reputation of the Prophet of the Lord, David Owuor, and the Ministry of Repentance and Holiness, but also the unity and testimony of our church.” the statement continued.

The ministry further urged media houses, bloggers, and social media users to verify information before publishing or sharing it, warning against the spread of misinformation that could mislead the public and cause unnecessary panic.

“As believers, we are called to pursue truth, peace, and righteousness. Let us not be quick to spread gossip, but instead be diligent in prayer, discernment, and unity,” the church noted.

Reports predicting the end of the world began circulating on various online platforms in late June 2025, claiming that Prophet Owuor had prophesied global destruction. The rumors quickly gained traction, sparking debate among Kenyans and international followers of the preacher.Prophet David Owuor, a controversial yet influential religious figure, is widely known for his large evangelistic rallies and trademark white suits. Among his followers, he is revered as a miracle worker and a man who has experienced several supernatural encounters.
The ministry reiterated that its teachings remain rooted in biblical repentance and holiness

blogs.title: Hell’s Nun
blogs.body:
A video showing a senior Catholic nun repeatedly slapping a younger nun at St. John's Rakwaro Minor Seminary in Homa Bay has gone viral, prompting an official response from the church and an internal investigation. The footage, widely circulated on social media, shows the older nun repeatedly striking the younger sister, who is heard asking, “Why are you beating me, Sister?” The incident is believed to have occurred on September 5, 2025.
On September 8, the Franciscan Sisters of St. Joseph (FSJ), also known as the Asumbi Sisters, released a statement addressing the incident. The Superior General, Sister Mary Goretty Ochieng, called the action a "personal failing" that "does not represent the values" of their congregation. Sister Ochieng added that violence of any kind is contrary to their core principles of "joyful love and compassion."

The FSJ leadership has assured the public that they are addressing the matter internally to ensure the “dignity and well-being” of their members. The Association of Sisterhoods of Kenya (AOSK) has also called for calm as the matter is handled through the appropriate internal channels.

Meanwhile, Kenyans on social media expressed shock and condemnation, with many calling for external investigations and stricter accountability within religious institutions. The debate has widened into concerns about safeguarding vulnerable members of the Church.

Abuse scandals have long troubled the Catholic Church globally. Since the early 2000s, inquiries in the United States, Ireland, Germany, and Australia have uncovered widespread physical, emotional, and sexual abuse, often concealed by Church authorities.

In Africa, cases have been less public but are surfacing more frequently. Reports from Kenya, Uganda, and Nigeria highlight abuses tied to power imbalances in seminaries and convents. Advocates say many victims remain silent, citing stigma, fear, and deference to religious authority.

blogs.title: “No bans from us” Nacada says
blogs.body:
The National Authority for the Campaign Against Alcohol and Drug Abuse (NACADA) has clarified that no bans have been introduced on alcohol advertising, online sales, home deliveries, or celebrity endorsements. The clarification follows public speculation after the launch of the National Policy for the Prevention, Management and Control of Alcohol, Drugs, and Substance Abuse earlier this week.

In a statement issued on Thursday, NACADA Chief Executive Officer Dr. Anthony Omerikwa emphasized that the policy document unveiled by the Cabinet Secretary for Interior and National Administration, Hon. Kipchumba Murkomen, is currently a set of policy recommendations and not enforceable law.

“We wish to emphasize that no bans have been introduced. These measures are currently policy recommendations, not law,” said Dr. Omerikwa. “Their inclusion aims to initiate legal and regulatory reviews, subject to proper procedures.”

Dr. Omerikwa noted that the policy is intended to serve as a guiding framework for addressing alcohol and substance abuse in Kenya. The next steps, he explained, will involve developing a multi-sectoral implementation framework that will engage key stakeholders from government agencies, industry players, civil society organizations, and the public.

He further assured that any proposals requiring legal backing will undergo a comprehensive and transparent review process, including wide-ranging consultations and public participation.
NACADA urged both the media and the public to interpret the policy as a roadmap rather than an enforcement directive, cautioning against misinformation about supposed bans or restrictions.

According to the authority, the goal of the policy is to protect young people from the dangers of alcohol and substance abuse, reduce harm, and promote a healthier and more productive society.
“The policy provides a foundation for constructive dialogue and coordinated national action on drug and substance abuse prevention,” NACADA concluded.

blogs.title: Blood Moon
blogs.body:
Tonight, Kenyans will have their eyes turned skywards as the country witnesses one of nature’s most mesmerizing spectacles. A total lunar eclipse, popularly known as the “blood moon’’ will grace the Kenyan Skies from 8:31 p.m., when the Earth’s shadow will completely cover the moon, painting it deep red. This phenomena will be visible across many places in the country with exceptional viewing places especially known for star gazing , among them the Mt. Kenya National Park where this reader joined natures’ enthusiasts among them academicians for a week long camp in anticipation of this historical, once in a lifetime occurence.

Astronomy enthusiasts and curious onlookers started flocking to the high-altitude region of Mount Kenya National Park at dawn a week ago where clear skies promise an unobstructed view of the celestial event.
“This is one of those moments where science meets beauty,” says Dr. Miriam Kilonzo, an astrophysicist at the University of Nairobi. “A total lunar eclipse like this occurs only when the Earth perfectly aligns between the sun and the moon, casting its shadow across the lunar surface. The reddish glow happens because sunlight is refracted through the Earth’s atmosphere. It’s like watching every sunrise and sunset on Earth reflected on the moon.

According to the Kenya Space Agency, the eclipse will begin at 6:28 p.m. with the penumbral phase, but the real show starts at 8:31 p.m. when the total eclipse begins. The moon will reach its darkest and most striking point around 9:12 p.m., before gradually returning to normal by 11:55 p.m.
For locals in the foothills of Mount Kenya, the event has stirred excitement and curiosity. Samuel Mwangi, a tour guide in Nanyuki, said many visitors have booked night hikes and camping experiences to catch the rare view. “We’ve had tourists coming from as far as Mombasa and even Uganda,” he said. “People want to see the blood moon from the highest point possible. It’s a great experience.”

But beyond the scientific wonder, cultural interpretations still thrive. Mama Gakenia, an elderly woman from Meru County, smiled as she shared her traditional view. “When the moon turns red, our grandparents used to say it’s the earth cleansing itself as a sign of renewal.’’

Experts have advised that no special glasses are needed for viewing as it is safe to watch with the naked eye. However, binoculars or telescopes can enhance the spectacle.
Warm clothing is recommended for those planning to stay outdoors, especially in high-altitude areas where temperatures drop after sunset.

As Kenyans gather under the open sky, the red moon serves as a reminder of the shared wonder that binds humanity across science, culture, and curiosity. “Moments like this connect us,” Dr. Kilonzo reflected. “They remind us how beautiful our universe can be.”

blogs.title: Regional Wrap- up
blogs.body:
Thursday, October 10, 2025

Dodoma, Tanzania.

Preparations are underway for the October general elections, with President Samia Suluhu Hassan cleared by the electoral body to defend her seat. Her leadership has drawn both praise and criticism. Supporters commend her for restoring stability and improving Tanzania’s global image, while critics argue that the race is far from fair.
“President Samia is practically competing against herself,” said Dr. Peter Mukawimwana, a political analyst in Dar es Salaam. “Her main challenger, Tundu Lissu of the Chadema Party, is facing treason charges, making it difficult for the opposition to campaign freely.”

Kampala,Uganda

Long serving leader Yoweri Museveni has once again been cleared by the National Resistance Movement (NRM) to contest for another term, setting up yet another confrontation with opposition leader Robert Kyagulanyi, popularly known as Bobi Wine.
The political climate remains tense, with reports of violence and intimidation at opposition rallies. The situation worsened this week when two Kenyan human rights activists, Bob Njagi and David Oyoo, were reportedly abducted in Kampala. The two had been en route to meet Bobi Wine when their vehicle broke down. Witnesses allege that men believed to be police officers took them away.Their disappearance has sparked outrage among Kenyan activists, who have threatened demonstrations. “We just want them back home safely,” said Lydia Oyoo, sister to one of the missing men. The Kenyan Ministry of Foreign Affairs remains tight-lipped over the grievious human righys violations.

ADDIS, Ethiopia

Meanwhile, in Ethiopia, hope is rising following the official launch of the Grand Renaissance Dam, Africa’s largest hydroelectric project. Experts say the dam will significantly boost energy production and regional trade.
“This project is a symbol of progress,” said Dr. Tesfaye Alemu, an energy researcher in Addis Ababa. “It shows that East Africa can still move forward, even amid political challenges.”

blogs.title: Historic Israel-Hamas Ceasefire Deal Takes Effect, Hostages Freed
blogs.body:
A long-awaited ceasefire agreement between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas has taken effect, bringing the first significant pause in the devastating two-year conflict in Gaza and leading to the release of all remaining living Israeli hostages. The deal, brokered through intense international mediation, marks a critical initial step in a broader peace plan.

The truce, the first phase of a broader 20-point peace plan unveiled by US President Donald Trump, saw all 20 living Israeli hostages returned on Monday, days after Israel's cabinet formally approved the arrangement. In exchange, Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners and detainees.

The agreement mandates a significant surge in humanitarian aid, with up to 600 trucks per day expected to enter Gaza, according to the White House plan. However, the fragile truce faced an immediate test on Tuesday when Israel halved the aid flow, citing delays in the return of the remains of deceased hostages by Hamas.
The sentiment of cautious relief and high stakes was palpable. Khalil al-Hayya, a senior Hamas official and lead negotiator, reflected this during a televised speech, saying, “We declare today that we have reached an agreement to end the war and the aggression against our people.” Meanwhile, families of the hostages expressed "overwhelming joy and relief" at the news of their loved ones' return, according to the Hostages and Missing Families Forum.

The conflict, which erupted on October 7, 2023, following a massive attack by Hamas on southern Israel, has led to a major Israeli military offensive in the Gaza Strip. The operation has resulted in widespread destruction and the deaths of tens of thousands, overwhelmingly Palestinians, according to Gaza authorities. Previous attempts at sustained ceasefires, including one in November 2023 and another in March 2025, failed to hold.

This breakthrough deal, mediated primarily by the US, Egypt, and Qatar, requires a partial withdrawal of Israeli troops to new agreed-upon lines within Gaza, focusing on the immediate exchange of captives and prisoners and a massive boost in aid before tackling thornier issues like Hamas disarmament and future governance of the enclave. The US has committed to sending approximately 200 troops to Israel to help monitor the ceasefire and facilitate aid delivery.

blogs.title: Matiang'i Gets Jubilee Nod for State House Bid
blogs.body:
Jubiliee Party, has officially endorsed Dr. Fred Matiang'i as its presidential candidate for the 2027 general election.

In an announcement that was made during a high- level National Executive Committee (NEC) meeting held in Nairobi, the Party's Secretary-General Jeremiah Kioni said the decision reflects the party's confidence in Dr. Matiang'i's leadership record and his ability to steer the country forward.

This is not only a significant political development, but also a major comeback for both Dr. Matiang'i and the party.

In his rise to prominence, Dr. Matiang'I, who is the former Interior Cabinet Secretary has been appointed to deputize former President Uhuru Kenyatta in the part leadership structure. The endorsement positions Matiang'i as a key player Kenya's 2027 electoral landscape.

Jubilee Party which has been working to revitalize its grassroot structures and re-engage with supporters nationwide, is seen to be using Matiang'i's endorsement as a strategic move to rebrand the party and provide a fresh perspective on leadership.

The Party's NEC has also approved a nationwide member registration drive which aims at reenergizing the Party's grassroot networks and rebuilding public confidence.

However, Jubilee Party's relationship with the United Opposition remains intact despite Matiang'i's endorsement as the party's presidential candidate.

Jeremiah Kioni emphasizes that the party will review its position in the coalition carefully, citing potential legal implications for certain parliament members if they were to exit the alliance.

Matiang'i's appointment as Jubilee's representative in the United Opposition is expected to strengthen the party's negotiation power in coalition talks.

He has pledged to focus on national unity, service delivery and institutional reforms if elected president. His campaign is expected to emphasize good governance, education reforms, security enhancement and economic revitalization.

Matiang'i's experience in public service and his reputation for firm leadership are seen as key asserts in his bid for presidency.

blogs.title: Governor - Senator Rivalry Threatens Kakamega Development Agenda
blogs.body:
Kakamega Governor, Fernandes Barasa has called out Senator Bonny Khalalwe after he allegedly assaulted a County Executive Committee Member (CECM).

Senator Khalwale is accused of physically assaulting CECM for Finance, Benjamin Andama, during a senate oversight visit on Friday.

In an official statement released on October 4, 2025, Governor Barasa condemned the act, stating it undermined the spirit of mutual respect essential for devolution. The incident reportedly occurred at the Kakamega County Level 6 Teaching and Referral Hospital during a visit by the Senate Devolution Committee, though Senator Khalwale is noted as not being a member of that visiting committee.

According to the statement, Senator Khalwale joined the committee comprising Senators Mohammed Abass, Richard Onyonka and Catherine Mumma and during the session, he assaulted Mr. Andama. The Senator's actions were allegedly streamed live on social media and further compounded by derogatory remarks in which he belittled the CECMs and Chief Officers as very junior people.

Governor Barasa, who also chairs the Council of Governors' Finance, Planning and Economic Affairs Committee, called upon the Speaker of the Senate, Amason Kingi, to launch an investigation, take firm action to protect the integrity of the Senate's oversight role and safeguard devolution. He also urged law enforcement agencies to ensure justice for CECM Andama.

The Kakamega County Government stressed its commitment to working respectfully and cooperatively with the Senate.

"The County Government of Kakamega welcomed the Senate in good faith, with full expectation that the inspection and any interrogations would be constructive and professional", the statement read.

The Governor's office reaffirmed its recognition of the Senate's constitutional mandate under Article 96 to oversight county governments and protect their interests. It cautioned that oversight sessions must not be turned into platforms for personal ambition or political campaigns.

blogs.title: Mutai Escapes Ouster as Impeachment Bid Fails
blogs.body:
Kericho County Governor Erick Mutai, has once again survived another impeachment after a Senate ruling.

The Senate ruled that the County Assembly failed to meet the required threshold in its impeachment motion with 33 out of the 47 Members of the County Assembly (MCAs) voting for his removal.

The impeachment motion, tabled in the county assembly on August 15, 2025, accused Governor Mutai of gross violation of the constitution, abuse of office and financial misconduct including authorization of an illegal payment of Ksh 85 million to 46 companies for undelivered work and unlawful dismissal of staff.

However, during the Senate hearing, it was found that the process had serious irregularities, citing concerns over the voting system used by the assembly, as non-compliant with Article 88 of the constitution.

Governor Mutai called the process "predetermined" and highlighted the use of an SMSbased voting system that he said lacked transparency and credibility.

Following the Senate's decision on August 29, 2025, the assembly's motion was terminated and Governor Mutai resumed his duties, stating he would continue leading the county with renewed focus.

Political observers have warned that the Governor might continue to face hostility from the MCAs, hampering service delivery and stability in Kericho County.

If the county assembly addresses the procedural concerns and re-initiates the process correctly, the matter could resurface and the Governor may face another test of his leadership.

blogs.title: IEBC Assures of Commitment to Fair Elections
blogs.body:
The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) has issued a strong disapproval of election malpractice statements circulating within the country, urging Kenyans to disregard them.

In a press release issued from Nairobi on Sunday 13th July 2025, the Commission termed the statements as "unacceptable and reckless" and assured of fair, credible and verifiable elections.

This statement comes a day after Wajir Woman Representative Fatuma Jehow in an event at Wajir High School, expressed confidence in President Ruto's victory in 2027 elections for his second term, even through stealing of votes.

Contrally, IEBC reiterated that Kenya is not currently in a campaign period and called upon all stakeholders, particularly those in the political arena to refrain from actions that erode public trust and instead work to strengthen the electoral framework.

The IEBC highlighted its role in constituting the Electoral Code of Conduct Enforcement Committee, as prescribed by Article 84 of the Constitution of Kenya, 2010 and Section 110 of the Elections Act which governs the behaviour of political parties and their candidates during elections.

The Commission is now fully constituted after the re-gazettement and swearing in exercise of the Chairperson, Erastus Ethekon Edung and six Commissioners by Chief Justice Martha Koome. The Commissioners also elected Fahima Araphat Abdallah as the Vice Chairperson.

blogs.title: IEBC Warns Against Reckless Election Malpractice Claims
blogs.body:
Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) has issued a strongly worded statement warning against what it describes as "reckless and unacceptable" allegations of election malpractices currently circulating in the country.

The commission is calling on Kenyans to remain calm, stay vigilant and avoid being swayed by unfounded claims that could threaten national unity and trust in democratic institutions.

In a press release dated Sunday, July 13, the IEBC expressed deep concern over recent public statements alleging electoral misconduct. The commission described such utterances as "dangerous in a democratic society" and urged citizens to ignore or disassociate from those propagating them.

"Such reckless claims risk eroding public confidence in our democratic systems," the statement read. "We urge all Kenyans, especially political actors, to refrain from making or amplifying unsubstantiated allegations that may destabilize the country."

The IEBC clarified that Kenya is not currently in an election period, emphasizing that no elections have been declared or gazetted.

According to the commission, the Electoral Code of Conduct Enforcement Committee mandated under Article 84 of the, 2010, and Section 110 of the only operates during officially declared election periods. The commission cited a 2022 judgment by Hon. Sabina Chege in the (Petition No. 23/E026 of 2022), which clarified that the committee cannot act outside of an election period.

"Currently, there is no gazette notice or official declaration initiating an election period," the IEBC stated, adding that Kenya is not in a campaign season.

The commission further assured Kenyans that it is fully constituted and actively engaging stakeholders including political parties and leaders on ways to strengthen trust in the country's electoral processes. IEBC said it remains steadfast in its mission to ensure free, fair, and credible elections anchored in the rule of law and international best practices.

In an appeal to political players, the commission urged restraint and responsibility:

"We call upon all stakeholders to desist from utterances or actions that could undermine public trust in the electoral system. Instead, let us work together to rebuild and safeguard confidence in our democratic processes."

The IEBC reaffirmed its commitment to safeguarding its independence and impartiality as enshrined in the Constitution. It pledged to continue upholding transparency and credibility in all its undertakings, stressing that the strength of Kenya's democracy depends on collective responsibility and public trust.

For accurate and up-to-date information, the commission encouraged citizens to rely on its official platforms, including its website and social media pages, rather than unverified sources.

As the country navigates this sensitive political atmosphere, the IEBC's message was clear: Kenya's democracy is a shared responsibility and it is worth protecting.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: The IEBC Condemns Reckless and Unacceptable Election Malpractice Claims
blogs.body:
The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) has expressed concerns over election malpractices claims in the country urging Kenyans to dissociate with such utterances.

They have considered the claims "unacceptable and reckless" in a democratic society like Kenya.

In a press statement, the commission affirmed that there has not been gazettement nor declaration to warrant such desirous political utterances and propaganda.The statement emphasized that "the country is not on a campaign period at the moment".

In reference to judgement of Hon. Sabina Chege Supreme Court Petition No. 23(E026) of 2022, the IEBC insisted that it will constitute the Electoral Code of Conduct Enforcement Committee as prescribed Under Article 84 of the Constitution of Kenya, 2010, and Section 110 of the Elections Act with which it has jurisdictions only during election period.

"IEBC is now fully constituted and will engage with stakeholders including the political parties and leaders to discuss means and ways of restoring trust and confidence in our electoral processes and outcomes," the commission announced.

The IEBC also appealed to all stakeholders particularly those in the political arena to refrain from acts including speeches likely to erode trust and confidence in the country's electoral processes

Further, the commission assured the members of the public and stakeholders that it shall safeguard its independence and impartiality while discharging its constitutional mandate and its functions as well as remain committed to ensuring free, fair and credible elections in accordance with the laws of Kenya and best practices.

The concerns over the independence of the IEBC have been a matter of public interest in the country since the declaration of the ruling party after the 2022 National elections.

This has just been stimulated by the rising issues of abduction and ever heating demonstrations of the Gen Zs over government's acts that they claim to be lacking transparency and accountability and the recent appointment of the commission's members that have been associated with tribalism and political interests of the ruling party.

Various Human Rights defenders and Civil Societies who are now looking into the operationalization of the IEBC in a way that shall demonstrate democracy and inclusivity in the country have just been triggered to join and be on the watch.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: Tanzania Protests Spark Fears of Growing Insecurity
blogs.body:
On 29 September 2025, thousands of people took to the streets in several Tanzanian cities to demand political freedoms, accountability and justice for missing persons.

The demonstrations, which were most visible in Dar es Salaam, Dodoma and Arusha, were the latest in a series of protests that have unfolded over recent months, raising concerns about rising insecurity ahead of the upcoming general election.

Protesters carried placards calling for protection of rights to assemble, free expression and reform of the electoral process. In many areas, the rallies were met with heavy police presence. Officers ordered crowds to disperse, speeches were interrupted and some demonstrators were arrested. Restrictions were also reported on social media posts about the events.

The protests follow growing allegations of abductions, intimidation of critics and harassment of journalists. Human rights groups say they have documented cases of politically motivated assaults and disappearances. In a recent incident that drew international attention, two activists from Kenya and Uganda claimed they were detained, tortured and then deported after entering Tanzania to support opposition activity.

Observers believe the unrest is linked to tensions surrounding the general elections scheduled for 29 October. Opposition leaders and civil society groups accuse the government of creating a hostile political environment by curbing dissent, silencing the press and limiting the independence of electoral institutions. Police have also blocked several planned demonstrations by lawyers, activists and opposition members.

The wave of protests and the forceful responses have left many citizens anxious. Residents in affected areas say businesses close during rallies, transport is disrupted and checkpoints slow movement. Some families of those reported missing live with constant fear while young people and students worry about being caught up in confrontations.

Despite the risks, many Tanzanians remain determined to make their voices heard. In Dar es Salaam, one woman held a sign that read "My voice matters" and told reporters, "I will not be silenced by fear." Similar sentiments were echoed in other cities as crowds chanted for justice and democracy.

As the election date approaches, the demonstrations highlight both the determination of citizens to push for change and the uncertainty of how the government will respond. For many, the protests of 29 September mark either a turning point or yet another warning of the fragile state of freedoms in Tanzania.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Protest and Unrest in Tanzania Following the Country's General Election
blogs.body:
Tanzania is experiencing widespread protest and unrest following the country's recent general election, that excluded the two main opponents in the presidential race.

Though Tanzania is a democratic nation with a freedom of multiparty, the opposition parties, CHADEMA and ACT-Wazalendo were both barred from participating in the election leading to allegations of electoral irregularities and a lack of transparency.

"These results have no basis in reality, as truth is that no genuine election took place in Tanzania", said Tundu Lissu, the CHADEMA leader.

According to Amnesty International, Police have used tear gas and live ammunition to disperse protesters in several cities including Dar es Salaam, Mbeya, Tunduma, Tanga and Mwanza, with at least two people being reported dead and several injured.

As a result, the government has imposed a nationwide internet blackout making it difficult for protesters to communicate and for information to be disseminated.

Additionally, curfew has been imposed in Dar es Salaam with police instructing residents to remain indoors after 6pm.

Security forces have also deployed to maintain order and prevent further protest with authorities warning against defying the curfew.

In reaction to the unrest, the US Embassy in Dar es Salaam has issued a security alert advising American citizens to avoid demonstrations and crowded places. Amnesty International and other human rights organizations have also condemned the government's response to the protesters calling for an investigation into the use of force.

The situation in Tanzania remains tense with protesters continuing to defy the curfew and security forces maintaining a heavy presence in the streets.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: Kenya Mourns Raila Odinga, A Statesman of Enduring Legacy
blogs.body:
Former Prime Minister and leader of the opposition party ODM, Raila Odinga has died at 80.

Popularly referred to as 'Baba' by his supporters, Raila died in India to from cardiac arrest while receiving treatment.

Thousands of people gathered at the state funeral held in Nairobi and later at his home in Bondo, western Kenya, where Odinga was buried next to his father. A seven-day national mourning period was declared and flags flew at half-mast in his honour.

Odinga rose from harsh beginnings to become one of Kenya's most influential leaders. As a young man he endured detentions and battles for multiparty democracy under the one party rule of the 1980s. He later became Prime Minister from 2008 to 2013, playing a key role in the 2010 constitution and in stabilizing the country after post-election violence.

His legacy goes beyond politics. Odinga was a mentor and father figure to many, especially in his Luo homeland, where crowds chanted "Baba we love you" as his casket arrived. He encouraged youth participation, championed devolution of power and inspired a generation to believe in change.

During the burial service, community leaders and ordinary citizens alike reflected on the importance of unity, service and resilience fashioned in Odinga's life. They noted how he used his voice for the voiceless and stood firm amid adversity.

There are tangible lessons from Baba's passing including, leadership grounded in principle endures beyond the individual, the bonds between leader and people matter not only in policies but also through empathy and presence and lastly his death serves as a reminder that living a public life requires integrity and leaving a legacy demands courage.

As Kenya moves forward without its formidable "Baba," citizens are asking: who will carry forward his vision of democracy, inclusion and hope? The streets are quiet now, but the call to serve remains loud. In honouring Raila Odinga's memory, the nation may find strength in unity and purpose once more.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Man Murders Father Over Sukumawiki Dispute
blogs.body:
A 39-year-old man killed his father during a confrontation over a bunch of Sukumawiki in Emailndi, Kakamega.

According to Police reports a 70-year-old, Milton Abednego, had a disagreement with his son over a bunch of Sukumawiki which the son had plucked from the nearby farm.

The son is said to have plucked the vegetables without getting permission from his father therefore leading to the confrontation.

When the son was confronted, he hit the father with a panga on the head who bled to death.

The son escaped but was later on tracked down by angry villagers who lynched him to death.

Police have moved the bodies to the mortuary as they wait for an autopsy to be done.

The panga that was used to commit the offence has been recovered and police have encouraged members of the public to surrender suspects to the authorities instead of taking their own action.

Murder cases in Kakamega County as a result of family disagreement, especially food related, are rampant. In 2020, a man hacked his wife to death after fighting over ugali in Emuhaya village.

Similarly, in Seregeya, Likuyani sub-county, two brothers fighting over a meal of ugali and omena (sardines) ended in the death of their step brother who had intervened to resolve the disagreement in July 2022.

It is not known whether these incidents are triggered by long term feuds.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Teenager Invents Own Prosthetic Arm
blogs.body:
17-year-old Brian Kiptoo has crafted a working prosthetic arm from discarded metal and plastics.

Brian, a resident of Kipkelion lost his right arm three years ago in a tragic farm accident involving a chaff cutter.

Coming from a low-income family, the cost of a medical-grade prosthetic—estimated at over Ksh 350,000, was far beyond their reach. His determination to regain independence set him on a different path.

"I couldn't accept that I would depend on people forever," Brian said, smiling shyly as he demonstrated the arm's grip mechanism. "I wanted to build something that could help me write, eat and maybe even play football again."

Using scrap materials collected from a local garage, bicycle chains and old wires, Brian spent nearly six months assembling the device. The arm is powered by a simple lever system connected to his shoulder, allowing him to open and close a makeshift metallic palm.

Meanwhile, his story caught the attention of Kericho Technical Institute, where engineers have offered to help refine his prototype.

"What Brian has done is incredible, it's a symbol of ingenuity and resilience," said Dr. Peter Langat, a Mechanical Engineering Lecturer who volunteered to mentor him.

The Ministry of Education has reached out to explore ways of supporting young innovators like Brian through its Science and Innovation Grant.

"If my invention helps even one more person like me, then I'll be happy," he said.

The county government has also promised to fund his education and link him to national innovation programs.
blogs.author: Ronny Choge

blogs.title: Nairobi River Cleanup Brings Hope and Hardship
blogs.body:
The clean-up of the Nairobi River has given the city a fresh chance at renewal, but also left thousands of families and business owners counting their losses.

According to the Ministry of Interior, more than 181,000 people were relocated from riparian reserves along the Nairobi River, Mathare and Ngong rivers (tributaries of the Nairobi River).

Over 40,000 households vacated areas deemed unsafe and were each given ten thousand shillings to help them move.

Former Cabinet Secretary Kithure Kindiki said the relocations were part of a larger plan to prevent flooding and restore river ecosystems. "We have to protect lives and property. These areas are dangerous and no settlement should be allowed there," he said.

The demolitions hit both homes and businesses. In Kileleshwa, the National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) pulled down a popular coffee outlet, a petrol station and a pharmacy after declaring them too close to the river.

The Shariff brothers, owners of Safe Dose pharmacy, told reporters that property worth millions of shillings was destroyed. "We did not have time to salvage everything," they said.

For families, the impact was personal. Mary Akinyi, a trader who lost her kiosk in Mathare, says she had to start life all over again.

"It was painful, I had no income for months. But I can already see the river looking better, and that gives me some hope," she explained.

Community groups and aid organizations stepped in to cushion the affected. Religious institutions offered temporary shelter while charities provided food and clothing. Some residents were also linked to the affordable housing program.

Meanwhile, NEMA and the Water Resources Authority were pushing forward with the restoration. So far, 35 kilometres of the Nairobi River stretch have been cleared. The government also reports that more than 272,000 seedlings were planted and 268 tree nurseries established.

Young people are playing a central role through the Climate WorX programme, which recruits between 20,000 and 50,000 youth and women to clean the rivers and plant trees. President William Ruto has said that the initiative will not only restore the river but also create jobs.

Nairobi Woman Representative Esther Passaris, however, criticised the demolitions, arguing that some families were displaced without notice.

"We must restore the river, but we must also respect the dignity of those affected," she told Parliament.

The Nairobi River story is now one of both progress and pain. The waters are slowly clearing, the banks are being replanted, and the city is reclaiming a long-polluted lifeline. But the voices of those displaced remain a reminder that environmental renewal often comes with a heavy human cost.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: NACADA Dismisses Alcohol Ban Reports
blogs.body:
The National Authority for the Campaign Against Alcohol and Drug Abuse (NACADA), in a press statement has clarified on the circulating misinformation in the media regarding alcohol, drugs and substance abuse policy.

This follows the launch of the National Policy for the Prevention, Management and Control of Alcohol, Drugs and Substance Abuse (2025) by Cabinet secretary in the Ministry of Interior and National Administration Hon. Kipchumba Murkomen in Nairobi.

In the statement, the NACADA's Chief Executive Officer Dr. Anthony Omerikwa, pointed out that, it was a national policy, which was contrary to reports that suggested NACADA had banned certain practices such as alcohol advertising, online sales, home deliveries and celebrities' endorsements. He emphasized that no bans had been introduced.

Additionally, the CEO informed Kenyans that those measures were currently policy recommendations and not law and that, their inclusion aims to initiate legal and regulatory reviews, subject to proper procedures.

He also disclosed to Kenyans that the next step after the launch was the development of a multi-sectoral implementation framework, bringing together stakeholders from government, industry, civil society and the public.

"This would set out practical steps towards achieving the policy's aims. Any proposal that requires legal backing will undergo a thorough law review process, which will be transparent and inclusive," he asserted.

In his directives, the CEO however, affirmed that most importantly, public participation would be central to this process and that, this will enable citizens, businesses and interest groups to share their views and address any contentious issues before implementation.

"We urge the media and the public to treat this policy as what it is, a roadmap, not an enforcement measure. NACADA's goal, as clearly outlined in the policy, is to protect our youths from the danger of alcohol and substance abuse, reduce related harm and foster a healthier, more productive society" he insisted.

Over the years, Kenyans through civil societies and other stakeholders have raised concerns over the issue of public participation on matters governance and general issues that concerns their overall wellbeing. In various instances, this democratic exercise has been reported to have not been carried out in a democratic way and that structures and formalities of public participation were not observed.

NACADA which has been in the fore-front fighting for a healthier society is not an exception on matters public participation when it comes to policy formulation and implementation. It's mandate to curb drug and substance abuse for a healthier society makes it subject to active engagement of stakeholders and societal structures that caries similar mandate.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: Policy, Not Prohibition: Moves to Quell Alcohol Ban Fears
blogs.body:
The National Authority for the Campaign Against Alcohol and Drug Abuse (NACADA) has moved to calm rising public anxiety after widespread media reports claimed that it had outright banned alcohol advertising, online sales and celebrity endorsements.

In a statement released shortly after the policy's launch in, the agency clarified that no such bans are in place. The launch was officiated by the Cabinet Secretary in marking what NACADA described as a "critical first step" toward addressing Kenya's growing burden of alcohol and substance abuse.

"Contrary to reports suggesting that NACADA has banned certain practices, we wish to emphasize that no bans have been introduced," read the statement signed by the NACADA Chief Executive Officer. "These measures are currently policy recommendations, not law. Their inclusion aims to initiate legal and regulatory reviews, subject to proper procedures."

According to NACADA, the policy should be seen as a roadmap, not an enforcement tool. The next phase involves developing an inclusive implementation framework that brings together voices from government, industry, civil society and the public. This process will outline practical steps to achieve the policy's ambitious goals while undergoing rigorous legal review and public consultation.

Dr. Omerikwa emphasized that public participation will be central to the process, stating that it will provide citizens, businesses and interest groups with an opportunity to share their views, address contentious issues and shape solutions before any legal measures are taken.

NACADA urged the media to exercise responsibility when reporting on the policy to avoid creating panic or misinformation. The agency's primary aim, it said, is to protect Kenyan youth from the dangers of alcohol and substance abuse, reduce related harm and nurture a healthier, more productive society.

"This is not about punishment or prohibition," the CEO stressed. 'It is about building a framework to protect our future generations and empower communities to take part in shaping how we tackle substance abuse as a country.'

The statement encouraged Kenyans seeking accurate information to rely on NACADA's official website and platforms for updates rather than unverified reports circulating online.

As the policy moves into its critical implementation stage, all eyes will be on how well the government balances firm regulation with broad-based dialogue ensuring that the path toward curbing alcohol and drug abuse is anchored in consensus, not coercion.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Authority Quashes Alcohol Ban Rumours
blogs.body:
National Authority for the Campaign Against Alcohol, Drugs and Substance Abuse (NACADA), has clarified that they have not banned alcohol sale and advertising.

The National Policy for the Prevention, Management and Control of Alcohol, Drugs and Substance Abuse, 2025 was launched on Wednesday, July 30th by the Cabinet Secretary in the Ministry of Interior and National Administration Kipchumba Murkomen in Nairobi.

Contrary to the media reports, NACADA says that the measures are only policy recommendations and not law.

"This is a national policy and contrary to reports suggesting that NACADA has banned certain practices such as alcohol advertising, online sales, home deliveries and celebrity endorsements, we wish to emphasize that no bans have been introduced", the press statement read.

It further stated, "We urge the media and public to treat this policy as what it is, a road map, not an enforcement measure."

NACADA further stated that it will form a multi-sectoral implementation framework that will help achieve the policy's main goal subject to a thorough law review process

NACADA was formed through an Act of Parliament to coordinate a multi-sectorial campaign to prevent, control and mitigate the impact of alcohol and drug abuse in the country and is known for the famous Mututho Law that regulated drinking hours.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Celebrated Journalist Laid to Rest in an Emotional Send- Off
blogs.body:
Journalists, friends and family gathered in Murang'a County to bid farewell to renowned media personality Kimani Mbugua, whose sudden demise left the nation in mourning.

Kimani passed away earlier this month and his body was transferred from Nairobi to his hometown for burial.

The funeral service took place at his ancestral home, where hundreds of mourners came to pay their respects. The emotional atmosphere was marked by heartfelt tributes to Mbugua's career, compassion and dedication. Family members recounted how he championed truth in journalism and touched lives beyond the newsroom.

Mbugua's death has stirred reflection among his peers and the broader community. Many noted the importance of mental health awareness within high pressure professions like media. Colleagues said he had been under increasing stress in recent years, and his passing serves as a reminder of work life balance.

The burial also underscored the enduring support of community bonds and the solace found in tradition. In his home village, local leaders emphasized the value of coming together in grief and of lifting one another up during difficult times.

Lessons from Mbugua's life and death are clear. First, pursue your calling with integrity as Mbugua did, always remembering the human story behind the headline. Second, care for yourself and those around you, no success is worth ignoring your health or emotional wellbeing. Third, treasure your roots and relationships, for they provide strength in life and comfort in passing.

As the final words were spoken and the casket lowered, one attendee said, "Kimani lived loud and gave much, let his memory remind us to live kindly and consciously."

His passing leaves a significant void in Kenyan media, yet his legacy continues through the lives he impacted.

Those touched by his work will remember him not just as a journalist, but as a friend, a mentor and a voice for others. In honouring him, many hope to carry forward his compassion and commitment.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Ojwang's Death Draw Sharp Rebuke from Senate
blogs.body:
The Senate has condemned the death of blogger Albert Ojwang while in police custody, terming the incident as a grave violation.

The Senate has condemned the death of blogger Albert Ojwang, who died while in police custody, turning the incident a grave violation that has shaken public trust in Kenya's security services.

Ojwang who was arrested in Homa Bay over allegations of spreading false information about a senior police official on social media, was transferred to Central Police Station in Nairobi, where police reported his death as due to sustained head injuries while in his cell.

The Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) has launched an investigation into the incident, while police have suspended the officers who were on duty at the time.

Activists and human rights groups, however, have rejected the official account, alleging foul play and linking the case to a pattern of police brutality witnessed during last year's nationwide unrest.

In a Senate session, Majority Leader Aaron Cheruiyot described the incident as a national tragedy, saying, "The tragic death while in police custody has deeply pained the conscience of our nation... one life lost is a life too many." He extended condolences to Ojwang's family and assured full cooperation with investigators to ensure justice is served.

Cheruiyot's remarks reflect growing concern among lawmakers over extrajudicial killings and deaths in custody, issues that have faced increased scrutiny from both IPOA and parliamentary committees in recent years.

Public outrage intensified on June 9, when protesters marched to police headquarters in Nairobi demanding justice for Ojwang. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd, sparking further condemnation from civil society groups who accused authorities of perpetuating impunity.

Organizations such as Amnesty Kenya have called for a transparent inquiry and the immediate release of IPOA's findings, warning against the suppression of dissent and misuse of police powers.

Authorities maintain that Ojwang died from a head injury, but observers continue to suspect foul play. The suspended officers remain under review, and IPOA's report, expected in the coming weeks, will determine whether prosecutions will follow.

Senator Cheruiyot pledge of accountability has added political weight to the probe, but human rights defenders and families of victims say they will be watching closely to see if the government's promises of justice turn into real action.
blogs.author: Ronny Choge

blogs.title: Trainee Succumbs After Being Shot by Police
blogs.body:
The Top Hill Hospital in Eldoret Uasin Gishu County has confirmed the death of a Kitale National Polytechnic trainee whose cause of death is alleged to have been a gun shot.

Dalphin Mwangi a 2[nd] year Electrical Engineering trainee in the Kitale National Polytechnic was allegedly shot by a police officer while playing pool with friends at Norec Shopping Center in Kibomet Kitale Town when a disagreement broke out between him and the officer.

Constable David Omondi, an officer attached at the Kitale Police Station in Trans Nzoia County allegedly drew his gun and shot Mwangi at close range in the stomach before fleeing the scene on a motorbike.

Responding officers Constable Martin and Oketch recovered two spent 9mm cartridges, a bullet head and bloodstains at the scene, confirming the shooting.

Mwangi who was rushed to Kijana Wamalwa Referral Hospital with a gunshot wound on the abdomen was later transferred to Top Hill Hospital for further treatment where he succumbed to his injuries changing the case to murder case.

The officer was arrested after an identification parade at the station and is being held pending arraignment.

The Independent Policing Oversight (IPOA) has also launched an investigation into the incident.

Police brutality has been on the rise in the country with college trainees and University students being the most affected.

In a related incident, a form 3 student was fatally shot within the Makunga Forest block of Saboti Forest Station in Trans Nzoia County a gazette forest area under the management of the Kenya Forest Service (KFS).

According to KFS, the shooting is alleged to have occurred during a law enforcement operation aimed at removing illegal invaders who had encroached on the forest land to cultivate and build structures.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: Human Rights Groups Drag Tanzania to Court Over Deportation
blogs.body:
A coalition of Kenyan legal and human rights figures has filed a lawsuit at the East African Court of Justice (EACJ) against the Tanzanian government.

They are accusing Tanzania's government of unlawful detention, denial of entry and deportation from Dar es Salaam on May 19.

The group which includes former Chief Justice Dr. Willy Mutunga, Senior Counsel Martha Karua, human rights activist Lynn Ngugi, Law Society of Kenya (LSK) Council Member Gloria Kimani, civil rights defenders Hussain Khalid and Hanifa Adan were deported from Julius Nyerere International Airport under unclear circumstances.

Speaking at a press briefing at the Millmani Law Courts on Tuesday, June 10, East Africa Law Society (EALS) President Ramadhan Abubakar said the deportation violated the East African Community (EAC) Treaty and the Common Market Protocol, which guarantees free movement of citizens across member states.

"According to EAC protocols, all citizens of member states have a right to free movement and residence across borders," said Abubakar.

He confirmed that the lawsuit had been lodged in Nairobi and would be forwarded to the court's headquarters in Arusha for hearing.

The group had travelled to Tanzania to observe the trial of opposition leader Tundu Lissu, former president of the Tanganyika Law Society and a vocal critic of the Tanzanian government. Lissu, who survived an assassination attempt in 2017, is faced with multiple politically linked charges.

Despite holding valid travel documents, the Kenyans were detained for hours at the airport, denied legal representation and deported on the next available flight to Nairobi.

"No justification or formal explanation was given for the refusal of entry," said Martha Karua. "We were treated like criminals in a country we consider part of a shared community."

Filed under the auspices of the EALS, the petition seeks a formal declaration that Tanzania violated regional laws, compensation for the affected individuals and removal of "refusal of entry" stamps from their passports.

Abubakar emphasized that the deportation undermines regional unity, noting that the integrity of the East African Community depends on the free movement of its citizens.

"This case goes beyond personal rights, it's a defense of the legal foundations of East African integration," he said

LSK President Faith Odhiambo condemned the deportations, confirming that the society fully supports the petition since one of its council members, Gloria Kimani, was directly affected.

"This action flies in the face of international diplomacy, mutual respect and the rule of law. We demand accountability," said Odhiambo.

Meanwhile, the incident has sparked debate on regional cooperation and diplomatic respect within the EAC. Neither the Tanzanian government nor its immigration department has issued an official explanation.

Critics argue that the deportation reflects growing intolerance toward external scrutiny of internal legal matters. On X (formerly Twitter), Tundu Lissu thanked the Kenyan delegation for their solidarity, calling the deportation "a stark reminder that freedom of movement and democracy remain fragile in parts of East Africa."

The EACJ, based in Arusha, is expected to begin hearings later this year. Legal experts say the case could set a precedent for how EAC citizens are treated and how the Common Market Protocol is enforced.

Should the petitioners win, Tanzania may be compelled to compensate the six Kenyans and lift their entry bans, strengthening regional unity and reaffirming respect for the rule of law.
blogs.author: Ronny Choge

blogs.title: African Israel Nineveh Church Bishop Found Guilty in a Land Fraud Case
blogs.body:
The Archbishop John Mweresa of the African Israel Nineveh Church has been found guilty of fraudulently acquiring church land in Jebrok, Vihiga County.

The church's land, a valuable asset acquired over the years, had become the focal point of a power struggle that would ultimately lead to Mweresa's downfall.

The African Israel Nineveh Church was founded in 1941 by David Paul Kivuli after breaking away from the Pentecostal Assembly Church of Canada, currently known as The Pentecostal Assembly of God- Kenya (PAG). The church has its headquarters in Jebrok Vihiga County and observes Friday as its Sabbath day, believing it to be the day of Jesus Christ's crucifixion.

The headquarters has been embroiled in internal conflicts and disputes over leadership and land ownership. The current dispute highlights the challenges faced by religious institutions in managing their properties and resolving internal conflicts.

The court case which has been ongoing for approximately 15 years, was marked by intense land disputes between the church followers and leaders leading to the church's closure and resulted in at least five deaths and multiple injuries.

The Hamisi Law Court delivered the verdict with Resident Magistrate Nicodemus Moseti ruling that there was sufficient evidence to convict Mweresa.

Mweresa's leadership has been contentious, with some members accusing him of wanting to remain in power forcefully.

His defense team had requested for a bond, but the magistrate rejected it citing uniform application of the law. He is therefore set for a sentence on November when the court shall determine his verdict after considering a pre-sentence report.

The conviction however, has brought a sense of relief to some church members who felt that justice has been served.

The court's decision marked a significant moment in the case, with potential far-reaching implications for church's leadership and stability.

As the church has been left to pick up the pieces and rebuild its image, the case has served as a stark reminder of the dangers of unchecked power and the importance of accountability, even in the highest echelons of society.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: Six Officers On Trial as Senior Cop Breaks Down in Court
blogs.body:
Emotions ran high in courtroom 8 at the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) headquarters in Nairobi as Senior Superintendent of Police (SSP) Dennis Omunga wept during his testimony.

He was appearing in the murder trial of six police officers accused of killing a suspected armed robber in the Kayole area.

Omunga, once OCS at Kayole Police Station, told the judges how his team had rapidly responded to a report of armed robbery at Kayole Junction. He testified that a homemade gun, ammunition and an identity card belonging to the deceased suspect were recovered at the scene. He described the area as "volatile" and said he lost 13 officers to criminal attacks while in command.

The case centres on the death of the suspect, Wickliffe Vincent Owuor, who was shot dead following a confrontation with police officers. Prosecutors allege the officers acted unlawfully and are seeking murder charges. The defence argues the officers acted in self-defence after being fired upon. Omunga's emotional breakdown underlined the weight of the situation both for the officers involved and the community they serve.

Civil society groups have expressed concern over the heavy use of force by lawenforcement in Nairobi's high crime areas, and this trial is seen as a crucial test of accountability for police shootings. The Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) has been criticised by Omunga for focusing on police conduct while, he claims, ignoring officers' deaths in the line of duty.

In the gallery sat relatives of both the accused officers and the deceased suspect, all listening in silence as Omunga described the moment of the shooting. Outside the courtroom, residents of Kayole said they welcomed the trial as an opportunity for justice but also voiced concern over the risks faced daily by officers in high crime neighbourhoods.

As the proceedings continue, the trial is likely to draw national attention, it underscores the delicate balance between security operations and human rights in Kenya's law-enforcement landscape. Many Kenyans will watch closely to see if this case leads to meaningful accountability, or simply another headline in a long series of police related deaths.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Canal+ Completes Multichoice Takeover in Billion-Dollar Deal
blogs.body:
CANAL+ has taken over Multichoice Group in a Zbillion US Dollars deal as approved by South Africa's Competition Tribunal.

The deal is set to expand CANAL+'s influence in English speaking regions in Africa while at the same time provide capital for MultiChoice Group local content and innovation.

"Today marks an important step forward for CANAL+, as we begin to integrate MultiChoice to create a group with enhanced scale, reach and creativity", said Maxime Saada, the CEO of CANAL+ in a statement.

The agreed deal includes a package of guaranteed public interest commitments proposed by the parties.

"Over the past three decades we've built something special- grounded in innovation, resilience and a shared commitment to bring great content to our audiences everywhere", Calvo Mawela, Chair, CANAL+ Africa, added.

MultiChoice Group will carve out its domestic unit into a new independent entity owned and controlled majorly by Historically Disadvantaged Persons, in order to abide with regulations that prohibit foreign entities from owning more than 20% of a South African broadcasting licensee.

CANAL+ was founded 40 years ago as a French-subscription TV Channel, and is now a global media and entertainment company with 26.9 million subscribers worldwide.

CANAL+ is home to StudiCanal, Dailymotion and Thema and enjoys equity stakes across Africa, Europe and Asia.

The deal between CANAL+ and MultiChoice Group has the potential of reshaping Africa's media landscape.

blogs.title: CBK, CBUAE Partner to Streamline International Transactions
blogs.body:
The Central Bank of Kenya (CBK) and the Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates (CBUAE) have signed two landmark Memoranda of Understanding (MoUs) aimed at deepening bilateral trade and improving the efficiency of cross-border transactions between the two nations.

The agreements, signed on June 3, 2025, in Abu Dhabi, will promote the use of local currencies including the Kenyan shilling and the UAE dirham, for international transactions while interlinking instant payment systems and secure financial messaging networks.

According to a joint statement by the two central banks, the first MoU seeks to reduce reliance on intermediary currencies such as the US dollar by encouraging local currency settlements.

The initiative aims to lower transaction costs, mitigate exchange rate risks and expedite payments for businesses and financial institutions.

"This agreement will encourage the use of local currencies in settling cross-border commercial transactions, enhancing the sustainable development of both financial markets," read part of the statement released by CBUAE.

For Kenya, the move comes amid broader efforts to de-dollarize regional trade, aligning with recent shifts across Africa to strengthen monetary independence. It follows a similar policy move in Tanzania, where authorities recently restricted the use of foreign currencies for local transactions to protect national economic sovereignty.

The second agreement focuses on digital payment interoperability, covering the interconnection of instant payment networks and national card switches. This will enable real-time, secure and affordable money transfers between the two countries, benefiting both consumers and businesses.

CBUAE Governor Khaled Mohamed Balama hailed the deal as "a game-changer in economic cooperation," noting that the integration of digital and currency systems would "broaden investment and commercial opportunities" for both nations.

Echoing the sentiment, CBK Governor Dr. Kamau Thugge lauded the collaboration as a natural progression for Kenya, a country recognized globally for its digital finance innovations such as M-Pesa.

"This cooperation will yield tangible benefits for both our citizens and investors. The interlinking of our two countries' payment systems marks a new chapter in economic modernization," Dr. Thugge said.

The UAE remains one of Kenya's leading trading partners and foreign investors. Data from the Ministry of Trade and Industry shows that bilateral trade between the two countries surpassed Ksh 150 billion in 2024, with key exports and imports including oil, electronics, tea and flowers.

Analysts say the new agreements are expected to accelerate trade, attract investment and create jobs by simplifying cross-border payments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and expatriate workers.

Regionally, the deal mirrors a wider African trend toward currency localization and digital integration, championed under the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) framework.

With inflationary pressures and exchange rate instability affecting global markets, many African central banks especially in Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa, are embracing policies that strengthen financial independence and resilience.

Although the Kenya-UAE agreements are bilateral, experts believe they could serve as a model for similar partnerships across Africa.

If successfully implemented, the framework could be scaled to other trade corridors, bolstering the continent's pursuit of a more digitally connected and self-reliant economy.

As global trade continues to shift amid geopolitical realignments, Kenya is positioning itself not only as a regional logistics and investment hub but also as a pioneer in financial and digital integration.

blogs.title: Kwale Air Crash Claims 11 Lives
blogs.body:
11 people have been reported dead following a plane crash near Vyungwani, Kwale County.

The Cessna 208B Grand Caravan-type operated by Mombasa Air Safari was traveling from Diani Airport to Kichwa Tembo in Masaai Mara National Reserve when it crashed in the hilly and forested area.

"The crash occurred moments after takeoff", said Abdillahi Alio, the Kwale Police Commandant.

According to Mombasa Air Safari spokesperson, there were no survivors confirmed in the tragic accident with the deceased including 8 people of Hungarian nationals, 2 German nationals and one Kenya pilot.

Weather condition in the area were reportedly poor with heavy rainfall and thick fog that morning which might have contributed to the tragedy. Witnesses reported hearing a loud bang before seeing flames and smoke rising from the wreckage which was scattered across the crash site.

The Kenya Civil Aviation Authority (KCAA) Director-General Emile Arao reported that, KCAA officers, emergency responders and other government agencies quickly responded to the incident dispatching rescue teams to the scene. The Aircraft Accident Investigation Department (AAID) has launched an investigation into the cause of the crash and to band asses its impact.

Though the incident has raised concerns about aviation safety in Kenya particularly involving light aircraft operations, with this incident marking another tragic accident in Kenya's aviation history highlighting the need for stringent safety measures, Emile Arao affirmed to Kenyans that aviation safety is top priority and were doing everything possible to ensure that their skies remain safe.

Investigations into the crash are ongoing on with authorities working to determine the cause and prevent similar incidents in the future. This shall include examining various factors including weather conditions, pilot errors and mechanical failures.

Mombasa Air Safari expressed profound sadness over the loss of lives extending condolence to the families of the victims. The Kenya Defense Forces (KDF) Spokesperson and other authorities including Transport CS Davis Chirchir also paid tributes to the victims emphasizing the importance of aviation safety.

blogs.title: 10 Family Members Killed in Kikopey Accident
blogs.body:
10 family members from Murang'a have perished in a road accident, involving a trailer in Kikopey, Nakuru County.

The deceased were among 17 members traveling for a family visit in Nakuru, using a 14 seater matatu on Sunday, driven by a family member.

"In that vehicle were my parents, Elija and Lydia Mburu, my sisters Pauline, Naomi, Joyce and Catherine and my nephew and uncle, recounted Patrick Mburu, one of the bereaved family members.

The visit was cut short when the matatu collided head on with a trailer along the busy Nakuru-Nairobi highway.

Those who survived are now fighting for their lives in hospital. The bodies of the deceased have been preserved at Nakuru PGH mortuary awaiting postmortem examinations.

The driver of the trailer involved in the collision explained that he attempted to avoid the matatu but could not.

"I tried to swerve, but the matatu seemed to be at high speed. It hit me", he said.

The families in Murang'a and Nakuru are still devastated and mourning a tragedy that has nearly wiped out the entire family.

The Kenya Airways Managing Director Mr. Wafula Mohamed confirmed that the plane had 179 passengers on board including the crew. According to the Kenya Airways Technician Miss Mwongela Rodah, The Jumbo Jet which was expected to land in Nairobi at the Wilson Airport in the next 5 hours had been checked and was in good condition for the flight.

However, 'the weather condition at the airport in the time of departure was not very conducive but much had been taken into consideration to ensure safety take off", she added

"My husband was in that plane, and what happened, when the plane started talking off, it again ascended very first into the ocean, and we can see plane parts are floating with some body parts, however we are not certain if there are any survivors, I am just hopeful that can see my husband once again", Miss Brigid an eye witness narrated.

With assurance, Mr. Wafula Mohamed informed the public that the rescue team including the French Navy, Red Cross and Kenya Navy were already at the scene to ensure the well-being of the passengers, crew and families.

He also informed media that the Kenya Airways understands the grief and trauma caused and that they shall stand with the team and families affected in this difficult time.

blogs.title: 159 Die as Kenya Airways Flight Crashes into the Atlantic Ocean
blogs.body:
A KQ plane headed to Nairobi crashed in Abidjan shortly after take-off killing at least 159 out of 179 passengers onboard including a cabinet secretary, top Kenyan government officials and a musician.

The Nairobi-bound Boeing 737 aircraft, Flight KQ458Y, was en route to Nairobi via Lagos, Nigeria, when it crashed into the ocean at approximately 8:00 PM West Africa Time (WAT), moments after departure. Authorities have confirmed that rescue efforts are underway, though chances of finding more survivors remain slim.

Speaking during a press conference in Nairobi, Kenya Airways Managing Director Wafula Mohammed expressed deep sorrow over the tragic event, offering condolences to the victims' families. "We regret to announce that Flight KQ458Y crashed into the Atlantic Ocean shortly after take-off. Initial reports confirm 159 fatalities and 20 survivors. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families and loved ones of those affected," he said solemnly.

According to Kenya Airways Technical Manager Rhoda Mwongela, the aircraft had undergone routine maintenance before departure and was in good condition. She added that the airline is fully cooperating with both international and local investigators to determine the cause of the crash. The black box has been recovered and is expected to shed more light on the cause of the accident.

Among those on board were 100 Kenyans, 30 Cote d' Ivoirians, 20 Nigerians and passengers from other countries including 2 from Burundi, 10 Britons,10 Americans, 2 Ugandans, 2 Tanzanians, 1 South African and 2 Rwandese. The passenger list included a Kenyan Cabinet Secretary attending an international conference in Abidjan, a well-known music celebrity and several senior government officials.

Family members of the victims have been flown to Abidjan to help identify their loved ones. Kenya Airways has set up emergency response centers in both Nairobi and Abidjan to provide updates and support to affected families.

Bridget Kamara, an eye witness who narrowly missed boarding the flight due to last minute work emergency described a chaotic scene.

"I saw the plane descend unnaturally immediately after take-off. Lifeguards are rushing up and down, parts of the plane and bodies are floating in the ocean and the airport is in panic mode. My husband was on the plane and I don't even know if he's survived", she said tearfully.

"Safety remains our top priority, and we are deeply saddened by this tragedy," Mr. Mohammed emphasized, promising that the airline would leave no stone unturned in uncovering the cause of the accident.

The government of Kenya has also extended its condolences and assured full support to the investigation and affected families.

blogs.title: Immune System Breakthrough Wins Nobel Prize
blogs.body:
Three researchers have been awarded the 2025 Nobel Prize in Medicine for discovering how the immune system protects the body from itself.

Mary E. Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell and Shimon Sakaguchi, have been recognized for their work on peripheral immune tolerance, the process by which the immune system avoids attacking the body's own tissues.

Sakaguchi first identified a previously unknown class of immune cells called regulatory T cells (Tregs) in 1995, showing that they act like security guards for the immune system.

In 2001, Brunkow and Ramsdell discovered the gene FOXP3, which is essential for the development and function of those regulatory T cells. They found that mutations in FOXP3 cause a severe autoimmune condition known as IPEX in humans and a related disorder in mice.

Together, their findings transformed how scientists understand immunity, not just as fighting infection, but also as controlling the immune system so it does not harm the body. These discoveries have paved the way for potential therapies for autoimmune diseases, cancer immunotherapy and better organ-transplant treatment.

Brunkow, born 1961, is a senior program manager at the Institute for Systems Biology in Seattle, Ramsdell, born 1960, is a scientific adviser at Sonoma Biotherapeutics in San Francisco while Sakaguchi, born 1951, is a distinguished Professor at Osaka University in Japan.

The announcement was made by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm on 6 October 2025, and the winners are set to receive their awards in December.

Their work underscores the delicate balance at the heart of human health, a powerful immune system that must also be restrained to prevent self-attack. With these findings, the "brakes" of the immune system are now understood, and medicine may harness them to treat disease more precisely than ever before.
