blogs.title: Nyong'o Propels Kisumu County to Universal Health Coverage
blogs.body:
Kisumu County Governor Prof. Peter Anyang' Nyong'o has launched the Digital Health Transformation Roadmap to enhance healthcare through digital solutions.

This includes a state-of-the-art Digital X-Ray, 128-slice CT scan and Mammography Center at Jaramogi Oginga Odinga Teaching and Referral Hospital (JOOTRH).

Prof. Nyong'o aims to achieve Universal Health Coverage (UHC) to provide seamless access to care in Kisumu County.

In an event that was presided by The Health Cabinet Secretary Aden Duale, the Governor initiated Medical Access and Reimbursement for Wellness and Affordability scheme (MARWA), a prototype ecosystem of the Universal Health Coverage (UHC) which has enhanced access to quality healthcare services among the residence in Kisumu County and the neighborhoods.

MARWA ecosystem which uses mobile data to prioritize care for vulnerable patient groups like pregnant mothers, digitizes records for better decision-making.

The ecosystem has grown insurance penetration in Kisumu County from 12% to 22% with a target of 70-75% by 2027. The county government has however gone ahead to cover half of the premium costs for individuals in the formal sectors who cannot afford to pay.

Prof. Nyong'o has also been involved in cancer initiatives which included launching of the Kisumu County Cancer Dashboard and participating in the Kenya International Cancer Conference.

His commitment to improving healthcare in Kisumu County is evident in his efforts to increase access to quality healthcare services, reduce healthcare costs and increase patient's outcome.

His successful spinal surgery at JOOTRH performed by a team of local and foreign doctors is a testament to the county's growing capabilities in complex medical procedures.

blogs.title: Blood Moon Lights Up Kenyan Skies
blogs.body:
Kenyans across the country witnessed a rare celestial event on the night of Sunday, September 7, 2025, as the moon turned red during a total lunar eclipse.

Popularly known as the Blood Moon, the occurrence lasted approximately 82 minutes, one of the longest duration for such an event with astronomers noting that the Moon was closer to Earth than usual, making it appear slightly larger and brighter.

The Blood Moon was visible across East Africa, Asia and parts of Australia, with the eclipse reaching its totality in Kenya from around 8:30 p.m. to 9:52 p.m. East Africa Time.

"We have that advantage of having some of the most beautiful and clear skies worldwide," said Jacques Matara, the Deputy Director of Space Research and Innovation at the Kenya Space Agency during an interview with AFP.

People flocked to open spaces to view and photograph the event with the Kenya Space Agency (KSA) sharing viewing tips and encouraging safer observations explaining that unlike the solar eclipse, lunar eclipse is safe to view with the naked eye.

A total lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth moves directly between the Sun and the Moon, casting its shadow across the lunar surface.

This Blood Moon is one of the most widely visible total lunar eclipses of recent years. The next total lunar eclipse will be in March 2026, however not with the same combination of duration, visibility and position as the September 2025 eclipse.

blogs.title: Kenya Gazes in Awe as Rare Blood Moon Paints the Sky Red
blogs.body:
Kenyans across the country were treated to a breathtaking celestial display on the night of September 7, 2025, as a rare total lunar eclipse popularly known as a blood moon lit up the skies with a deep crimson glow.

The event, visible from nearly all regions of Kenya, began shortly after sunset and reached its peak around 9:12pm. The phenomenon occurred when the Earth's shadow completely covered the Moon, filtering sunlight through the atmosphere and casting a reddish shade over its surface.

Sky watchers in Nairobi, Laikipia, and as far as Turkana described the sight as magical.

"It was one of the most beautiful nights I have ever witnessed," said Millicent Wanjiru, a university student who viewed the eclipse from the Nairobi Arboretum. "The moon looked like a glowing ember suspended in the sky. Everyone around me was in awe."

At Loisaba Conservancy in Laikipia, tourists and locals gathered on star beds to watch the spectacle unfold.

Wildlife guide Peter Leshan said it was a moment of unity and wonder. "We had guests from different parts of the world. People were quiet at first, then started cheering when the moon turned red. You could feel how small we are under that vast sky."

Astronomers confirmed that the September 2025 blood moon was one of the longest total lunar eclipses of the decade, lasting nearly an hour and twenty minutes. According to the Kenya Astronomical Society, the next comparable event will not occur until 2029.

The rare occurrence also stirred curiosity about astronomy among young Kenyans. Several schools in Nairobi, Nakuru and Eldoret organized night viewing sessions, giving students a chance to experience science beyond the classroom.

Experts reminded the public that blood moons are completely safe to observe without protective gear, as they differ from solar eclipses. Many who witnessed it described the night as peaceful and inspiring, a reminder of the beauty that lies beyond our world.

As the moon gradually returned to its silvery glow before midnight, Kenyans across the nation carried with them the quiet awe of witnessing one of nature's most stunning shows.

blogs.title: University Students Breathe Sigh of Relief as State Releases Billions in Funding

blogs.title: TSC Bans School Activities in Third Term

The Teachers Service Commission (TSC) has banned all social activities in schools during the third term.

In a memo addressed to regional, county and sub-county directors, TSC stated that the move is aimed at preventing disruption of learning and preparations for the national examinations and assessments.

"The Commission is deeply concerned with the social and related activities taking place in schools during this sensitive period", stated the memo.

Dated October 2, 2025, and signed by the Acting Commission Secretary/CEO, E. J. Mitei, the memo cites deep concern over non-academic activities taking place during what is described as a sensitive period of the academic year.

The Commission has directed all Heads of Institutions to ensure only activities involving learners and designated school Chaplains are permitted to take place and restrict interactions with external individuals.

The memo further stated that teachers' union campaigns will not be permitted to take place in schools, only allowing activities permitted by the Ministry of Education and TSC policy guidelines.

"All staff currently on leave should resume their duties to ensure the effective implementation of examination preparations", the Commission added.

The directive complements a Ministry of Education Circular dated August 27, 2025, which also focuses on a ban on social activities in the third term.

blogs.title: An Eye Over Integrity and Security of National Examinations in Kenya
blogs.body:
Exam Over 3.4 million students in Kenya have begun their national examinations marking a significant milestone in the country's education calendar.

The Kenyan Primary School Education Assessment (KPSEA) and Kenya Junior School Education Assessment (KJSEA) exams are being conducted across the country, with strict security measures in place to prevent cheating.

The exams which have been part of Kenyan's transition framework for learners from one level of learning to another has had tremendous changes in its administration due to the overall change in education system from 8-4-4 to 2-6-2-3.

KPSEA which is an exam conducted among the Grade 6 learners, ascertains their progress into moving to junior school. The KJSEA exams for Grade 9 learners assess their readiness to join Grade 10 under the Competency- Based Curriculum (CBC). The new system focuses on practical skills and critical thinking of trainees.

The National exams have over the years recorded issues of exams malpractices which made the publics doubt the integrity and security of the system.

In 2024, results for 711 candidates were canceled due to malpractice, highlighting the need for stricter measures to prevent cheating. Recently, a university student was charged with sharing a fake (Kenya Certificate for Secondary Education (KCSE) exam on WhatsApp, further emphasizing the importance of maintaining exam integrity.

The Kenya National Examinations Council (KNEC) has however, assured the public that all systems are in place to guarantee a transparent and seamless examination process and that, education officials and security personnel have been deployed to ensure the integrity of the exams.

The council has also put in place guidelines including strict protocol for handling examination materials and the prohibition of mobile phones within examinations centers. It has also implemented digital measures to secure examination materials, including the use of encrypted files and secure containers.

According to KNEC, the consequences of malpractice would include cancellation of results for candidates found engaging in malpractice and imprisonment of fines, with penalties ranging from 2 to 10 years imprisonment or fine of up to 5 million shillings.

The Ministry of Interior and National Administration has emphasized its commitment to upholding the integrity and security of national examinations, ensuring a fair and transparent process for all candidates.

Results for KPSEA and KISEA are expected to be released before Christmas.

blogs.title: Government Releases Higher Education Funding
blogs.body:
The Ministry of Education has reassured all Kenyans, especially students and learning institutions, of the government's strong and ongoing commitment to supporting access to higher education for all deserving learners.

In a press statement, the Ministry of Education Cabinet Secretary Hon. Julius Migos Ogamba affirmed to Kenyans that both HELB and Universities Funds had been facilitated by the Government to disburse funds to Universities and Students, and that, the disbursement of HELB loan for first-year university students would begin on August 15 2025, in line with the reopening of universities.

"To ensure no students is left behind, the Government has increased HELB's annual funding from Ksh. 36 billion to Ksh. 41 billion which presents a significant boost of Ksh. 5 billion, of which, Ksh. 13 billion had already been released to support tuition, and upkeep for students while Ksh. 16.9 billion had been allocated to the universities Fund for Scholarships", he stated.

Though there has been increased claims of delay in the disbursement of Scholarships and HELB funding as the main reason of increased numbers of drop-outs from various institutions of higher learning in the country, reports of "unfair" disbursement of Scholarships and HELB funding for higher leaning in the country which is referred to as "a give- and- take" game of cards has also been noted.

This has been an allegation from both the "have and the have not's" who claimed to have been left out due to their inability to raise the expected sum of money for their students to qualify for the various funding models.

Kenyans however, have in various forums urged the government to set up measures that would help ensure fair disbursement of Scholarships and HELB funds to all eligible students in the country without discrimination.

They have also called upon the Government to establish funding for the Secondary school education to help support learners from vulnerable families who struggle to meet their daily needs.

"This will help curb the issue of illiteracy in the country and boost the overall development of the country", they claimed

The CS guaranteed that the Ministry remains committed to ensuring that no eligible student is left behind due to financial constraints.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: National Exams Begin in Kenya Amid Calls for Integrity and Support
blogs.body:
More than 3.4 million learners across Kenya have begun their national examinations, marking a significant moment in the country's education calendar.

Kenya National Examinations Council (KNEC) reports 996,078 candidates sit for the Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education (KCSE), 1,298,089 for the Kenya Primary School Education Assessment (KPSEA) and 1,130,669 for the inaugural Kenya Junior School Education Assessment (KISEA).

The KISEA and KPSEA began on October 27 under the new Competency Based Curriculum (CBC), while KCSE commenced earlier on October 21. Education Principal Secretary Julius Bitok affirmed that all logistics are in place and that grade 9 learners will have placements in senior school for next year.

At the same time, Education Cabinet Secretary Migos Ogamba assured parents that no fees will be required for the ongoing exams, even amid a Ksh 3.7 billion budget shortfall for exam management. He stressed that the government remains fully responsible for administering the assessments.

Analysts say the 2025 exams are historic not only due to the massive number of candidates, but because it is the first to roll out the Grade 9 KISEA nationally. The shift to CBC and the new assessments mean learners are judged on competencies rather than memorisation.

KNEC has published strict guidelines to uphold boundaries around mobile phones, authorised personnel and the opening of exam packets to safeguard credibility yet a few challenges remain. Schools have been reminded to treat invigilators carefully and to ensure students are comfortable and not overly stressed during the exams.

As Kenya watches this large scale assessment unfold, many parents and teachers emphasize the need for calm, encouragement and a focus on learning rather than fear. The week ahead will test not just students' knowledge, but the resilience of the system and the spirit of the learners themselves.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Wave of Unrest Sweeps Kenyan Schools
blogs.body:
A wave of school fires has struck Kenya in recent days, with over 10 secondary schools experiencing violent student unrest.

The incidents have raised serious concerns as the country approaches national examinations, which are scheduled in just about a month.

Litein Boys High School in Kericho County was closed just hours after reopening on September 21, 2025, following student protests that left classrooms and other facilities destroyed. Parents arriving at the school expressed distress over the extent of the damage.

"I call upon TSC (Teachers Service Commission) to recall all teachers from Litein High so that we go back to the drawing board", said Mary Rotich the Executive Secretary for KUPPET, Kericho Branch.

Tengecha Boys High School was also after students went on a rampage. Members of the community had to intervene to put out a fire which they had started.

In the South Rift region, school administrators have been particularly anxious as incidents have involved some students wearing civilian clothing and covering their faces while destroying school property, making identification difficult.

Elgeyo Marakwet County has also experienced significant unrest across several schools, leaving both students and parents uncertain about the situation. Earlier in July, Tambach Boys High School in Iten was closed indefinitely after students staged an early morning march to the town's centre.

Similarly, 29 boarding schools in Gatundu South, Kiambu County were also closed and 25 students arrested over arson attacks. The step was taken by education officials to prevent further cases. According to them, the arsons were planned during the school holidays through whatsapp groups.

And recently in Nairobi County, St.George's Secondary School students were also sent home following unrest.

Questions are being raised about whether exam pressure is fueling the unrest or if deeper frustrations are boiling over among students.

Historically, student strikes in Kenya have represented acts of political expression, with students demanding that educational institutions fulfill their promise of justice and transformation.

The timing of these incidents is particularly concerning for education officials, as they threaten to disrupt preparations for the upcoming national examinations.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: 'No One Knows the Hour', Church Quashes End Time Claims
blogs.body:
The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness has issued a strong statement to dismiss widespread rumours circulating on social media claiming that the world will end on August 2, 2025.

In a press release dated August 1, 2025, the church condemned the claims as "false, baseless and malicious," warning that they are not only misleading but also damaging to the reputation of its spiritual leader, Dr. David Owuor and the ministry as a whole.

The statement, signed by Michael Nieswand, Senior Archbishop of the ministry, urged media outlets, bloggers, content creators and the public to avoid spreading or entertaining unverified doomsday predictions.

"Prophet Dr. Owuor has always been very clear that 'Nobody knows the day or the hour when the Messiah will return' as the Bible explicitly states in Matthew 24:36," the statement read in part.

According to the ministry, these rumours have been circulating online, causing unnecessary fear and confusion among the faithful. The church emphasised that its teachings have never involved setting dates for the end of the world, asserting that such actions go against biblical principles.

The leadership reiterated that they aim to prepare believers spiritually through repentance, holiness and righteous living, not to incite fear through sensationalist predictions.

The press release also referenced earlier clarifications issued by the church on 13 July 2025, which were broadcast on KBC News on 14 July and Radio 47 on July 15.

In a heartfelt appeal, the church called on Christians to focus on prayer, discernment and unity during times of misinformation.

"As believers, we are called to pursue truth, peace and righteousness. Let us not be quick to spread gossip, but instead be diligent in prayer, discernment and unity," the statement urged.

The ministry expressed concern that such rumours could distract believers from living out their faith and could tarnish the reputation of their leaders and church community, which has been hard-earned.

The statement concluded by reminding the public that salvation is a personal journey and not dependent on fear-driven prophecies or speculative dates.

blogs.title: Church Issues Clarification on 'World Ending' Remarks
blogs.body:
The leadership and congregation of The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness has strongly denounced the recent spread of information which they termed "false and misleading", about The world ending on August 2,2025.

In a press statement to all media houses and the general public yesterday, The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness Senior Archbishop Michael Nieswand, made it clear that Prophet Dr. Owuor has always been very Categorical on the fact that, "Nobody knows the Day or The Hour when THE MESSIAH will return as the Bible clearly states in Mathew 24:36".

He encouraged all media houses and the general public not to be quick to spread gossip, but instead be diligent in prayer, discernment and unity.

blogs.title: Church Backtracks On End of World Prophecy
blogs.body:
The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness has distanced itself from the widespread information of the world ending.

According to media outlets, the world was to end on August 2nd 2025 as prophesied by Prophet Dr. David Owour, of the Ministry of Repentance and Holiness.

The church leadership through a press statement has referred to the information as false and only meant to harm the unity of the church.

Additionally, the Church referred to the information as baseless and malicious.

The press statement read, "Prophet Dr. Owour has always been very categorical on the fact that nobody knows the day or the hour when the Messiah will return."

According to the Church, they had issued a statement earlier clarifying the issue, through two major local stations.

The Ministry of Repentance and Holiness and Prophet Owour have in the past been subject of controversial statements and activities, that emphasize on the preparation for the return of Jesus Christ.

The Church gained significant attention through its crusades that attracted a multitude of people having been founded by Dr. Owour in 2003.

Bloggers, media houses and content creators have been urged to refrain from sharing this information further.

blogs.title: D'Angelo, Neo-Soul Legend, Dies at 51
blogs.body:
Michael Eugene Archer, famously known as D'Angelo, the Grammy-winning American singer, songwriter and producer who helped define the neo-soul movement, has died at the age of 51.

His family confirmed that he passed away from pancreatic cancer in New York City after months of hospitalization and two weeks in palliative care.

D'Angelo had been working on his fourth studio album with longtime collaborator Raphael Saadiq before his death. The loss comes just seven months after the death of his former partner, singer Angie Stone, leaving their son Michael Archer Jr., known professionally as Swayvo Twain, mourning both parents within the same year.

Born on February 11, 1974, in Richmond, Virginia, D'Angelo rose to fame in the 1990s as a pioneer of the neo-soul genre. His debut album, Brown Sugar (1995) was certified platinum and credited with reshaping R&B through smooth, soulful melodies and heartfelt lyricism. The album included hits like "Lady," "Cruisin," and the title track, earning him widespread acclaim.

His second album, Voodoo (2000), debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 and cemented his legacy. The single "Untitled (How Does It Feel)" and its powerful video became cultural touchstones, winning him Grammy Awards for Best Male R&B Vocal Performance and Best R&B Album. Voodoo later ranked 28th on Rolling Stone's list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time.

Despite his success, D'Angelo struggled with depression and substance abuse in the early 2000s, leading to a long break from music. After years away from the spotlight, he made a triumphant return with Black Messiah (2014), a socially conscious and musically rich album that won two Grammy Awards, including Best R&B Album.

D'Angelo's influence extended far beyond his discography. Billboard named him among the greatest R&B artists, and in 2025, he was inducted into the National Rhythm & Blues Hall of Fame. His artistry inspired a generation of musicians, including Erykah Badu, Lauryn Hill, and Maxwell.

His three children, Michael Jr., Imani and a younger son born in 2010, survive him. D'Angelo's music, voice, and vision remain timeless reminders of the soul and vulnerability that defined his remarkable career.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Continental Concern: Africa Grapples with Armed Conflicts
blogs.body:
Africa continues to face multiple active conflicts and civil unrest across the continent, with conflict levels remaining persistently high in 2024 and continuing into 2025.

Dallia Abdelmoniem, a political commentator, who was forced to flee Khartoum says. "The one image I will always remember is that of bodies on the street in front of our house". She said this during a TV interview with Ajazeera while in Cairo.

The most severe crisis remains Sudan's civil war between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which began in April 2023. Nearly 12 million people have been driven from their homes, with over four million as refugees in neighboring countries.

Approximately 25 million people are experiencing extreme hunger, and in January 2025, the United States determined that the RSF and allied militias committed genocide. The SAF achieved strategic victories in North Kordofan, taking Umm Sumeima on September 26 and Bara on September 11, while consolidating control over the capital Khartoum, which it took from the RSF in March.

The humanitarian situation is dire, with over 60,000 cholera cases and more than 1,600 deaths reported between August 2024 and May 2025.

Elsewhere, a peace deal ending a conflict that killed tens of thousands in the neighbouring South Sudan is in danger of collapsing, raising fears over the world's youngest nation swiftly lapsing back into war. The country, which gained independence in 2011, has struggled with ethnic divisions and previous civil wars in 2013 and 2016.

In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), the M23 rebel group launched renewed offensives in the Eastern DRC in early 2025, allegedly with support from Rwanda, with key cities including Goma falling under rebel control.

In March 2025, M23 and FARDC allies became increasingly active following a ceasefire agreement.

Also, battles surged amid a Fano offensive in Ethiopia's Amhara region in March 2025, continuing internal conflict in the country.

And in Nigeria, military airstrikes against insurgents in Borno state increased in March, while conflicts persist in the Central African Republic and other regions across the continent.

The scale of displacement, hunger, and civilian casualties across multiple African conflicts represents one of the world's most significant humanitarian crises in 2025.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Eastern Congo Conflict Escalates as Battles Continue
blogs.body:
Renewed fighting in the Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has sparked urgent calls for peace from East African leaders.

This follows reports of intensified clashes between government forces and the M23 rebel group in North Kivu Province

According to the United Nations Mission in Congo (MONUSCO), at least 120 civilians have been killed and thousands displaced in the past two weeks, as violence spread near the towns of Goma, Rutshuru and Sake.

The humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate, with over 50,000 residents fleeing toward makeshift camps near the Rwandan and Ugandan borders.

Kenyan President William Ruto and his Ugandan counterpart Yoweri Museveni jointly appealed for restraint, emphasizing dialogue over confrontation.

"Peace in Congo is peace for the region," President Ruto said in a statement issued from State House Nairobi. "We urge all parties to prioritize the safety of civilians and recommit to the Nairobi Peace Process", he added.

Meanwhile, the East African Community Regional Force (EACRF), previously deployed to stabilize the area, has faced mounting pressure after the Congolese government accused some member states of bias.

Diplomatic sources indicate ongoing talks to redeploy African Union monitors to mediate between Kinshasa and rebel representatives.

Elsewhere, humanitarian organizations including the Red Cross and Doctors Without Borders have warned of a looming health crisis, citing shortages of food, water and medical supplies.

"We're seeing widespread malnutrition, injuries from shelling and rising cases of cholera," said Marie Nambasa, a Red Cross coordinator based in Goma.

The conflict, rooted in decades of ethnic tension and control over mineral-rich territories, has once again highlighted the fragile state of regional peace efforts. Analysts warn that if unchecked, the violence could destabilize neighboring countries and reverse recent gains in cross-border trade and cooperation.

As the world watches, the DRC's turmoil serves as a stark reminder of the urgent need for collective action to end a conflict that has already claimed millions of lives and continues to haunt Central Africa's quest for lasting peace.
blogs.author: Ronny Choge

blogs.title: Death Penalty for Kabila in Landmark Ruling
blogs.body:
The former president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Joseph Kabila has been sentenced to death in absentia.

A high military court found him guilty of treason charges, war crimes and other offences in connection with the ongoing conflict in the Kivu area.

Lieutenant General Joseph Katalayi, presiding over the tribunal declared Kabila guilty by a majority vote.

"In applying Article 7 of the Military Penal Code, imposes a single sentence, namely the most severe one, which is the death penalty", said Katalayi.

However, neither Kabila nor his legal team was present during the ruling.

Kabila is accused of a collaboration with the Rwanda based rebels M23, whose action resulted in deaths of more than 3,000 people.

Kabila who is now 53 years old, took office following the assassination of his father and former president, Laurent Kabila and served as president between 2001and 2019.

According to a report by Al Jazeera, the court also ordered Kabila to pay 29 billion US Dollars in damages to the DRC government and 2 billion US Dollars each to North and South Kivu.

With the whereabouts of the former president unknown, the court ordered for his immediate arrest.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: New EU Border Controls
blogs.body:
Kenyans planning to travel to Europe will be required to provide biometric data, a new measure introduced by the European Union (EU) to enhance security and travel processes.

This new requirement will take effect on October 12, 2025 and is set to beef up border security by enabling real time monitoring of travelers' movement.

Currently, the traditional manual passports are normally stamped during entry and exit into the European Union countries.

10 fingerprints and a digital photograph will be collected from people applying for the visa and the information recorded in a secure central database and is valid for a period of 5 years.

However, children under 12 years and people who physically cannot provide finger scans are exempted.

Travellers who frequent the Schengen Area will not be required to give new finger scans for every visit when applying for a new visa.

The European Union is set to fully implement the Entry/Exit System (EES) by April 10, 2026 and will affect all non-EU citizens visiting on Schengen Visa, including Kenyan citizens.

The Schengen Area comprises 29 European countries that have abolished internal border controls, facilitating passport-free travel for EU citizens and other individuals within this area legally.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Former French President Gets Prison Term
blogs.body:
70-year-old, former president of France, Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to five years in prison.

On Thursday 25, September, a court in Paris ruled that he is guilty on some counts in a trial linked to campaign funds in Libya.

According to CNN, the ruling made Sarkozy the first former president of modern France sentenced to actual time behind bars.

Sarkozy served as president, from 2007 to 2012 with a 53.1% win and retired from politics in 2017.

From the court ruling, he was cleared of passive corruption and other illegal financing charges but found guilty of criminal conspiracy.

He was accused of accepting campaign funding from the late Libyan Muammar Gaddafi with Franco-Lebanese businessman Ziad Takeddine as the intermediary.

Although Takeddine died recently in Beirut, he asserted that in 2006 and 2007 he had given a total of USD 6 million to Sarkozy's Chief of Staff in cash.

Prosecutors described the case as a "corruption pact" to help in clearing Gaddafi's image abroad when not so many people wanted to associate with him.

It is alleged that Gaddafi was the mastermind behind the airplane bombing in 1988 in Lockerbie. However, he was later killed by opponents in 2011 during the Arab Spring and NATO intervention in Libya.

Also co-accused in this case is Sarkozy's wife, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy for witness tampering.

This is not Sarkozy's first conviction as he faced two separate trials in 2021, receiving a three year and a one-year sentence, where he lost the appeal but was later revised in February 2024.

Sarkozy also plans to appeal this particular ruling although the court maintained that he will be incarcerated.

"If they absolutely want me to sleep in prison, I will sleep in prison. But with my head held high. I am innocent. This injustice is a scandal," Sarkozy said when addressing journalists after the ruling.

The date of his imprisonment has not yet been set.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Israel-Iran Tensions Flare After Deadly Airstrike in Damascus
blogs.body:
Tensions between Israel and Iran have escalated sharply following an Israeli airstrike in Damascus, Syria, that reportedly killed at least 12 people, including two senior Iranian military advisers.

The strike, which occurred late on September 13, marks one of the most significant confrontations between the two longtime rivals this year.

According to Syrian state media, Israeli fighter jets targeted a building in the Mazzeh district, an area known to host Iranian-linked personnel and pro-Hezbollah militias. The blast ignited massive fires, leaving dozens injured and nearby structures damaged.

The Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) confirmed the deaths of General Hamid Karimi and Colonel Farshad Moradi, accusing Israel of "terrorist aggression" and vowing retaliation.

In a statement broadcast on Iranian state TV, Tehran warned that the attack would "not go unanswered."

Meanwhile, Israel maintained its long-standing policy of ambiguity, neither confirming nor denying responsibility.

However, an Israeli defense official, speaking anonymously to international media, emphasized that "any threats emanating from Iranian positions in Syria will be neutralized decisively."

The airstrike comes amid growing regional volatility, with both nations engaged in a shadow conflict that spans Lebanon, Iraq, Yemen and the Red Sea.

Analysts say the recent attack signals a dangerous escalation that could draw in multiple actors, including the United States, which maintains a military presence in the region.

"The strike appears to be part of Israel's broader strategy to disrupt Iranian entrenchment in Syria," said Dr. Laila Ben-Ami, a Middle East analyst at Tel Aviv University. "But with each attack, the risk of direct confrontation increases."

The United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres has called for restraint, warning that continued escalation could destabilize the entire Middle East.

"This cycle of violence endangers not only Syria but global peace and security," his spokesperson said in a press briefing in New York.

As night fell over Damascus, rescue teams continued to search through rubble for survivors. For civilians caught between proxy wars and political posturing, the rising tension between Israel and Iran once again underscored the fragile peace hanging over a region long scarred by conflict.
blogs.author: Ronny Choge

blogs.title: 61 Dead as Islamic School Collapses in Sidoarjo, Netherlands
blogs.body:
The quiet town of Sidoarjo in East Java has been left in mourning after the tragic collapse of the Al Khoziny Islamic boarding school that claimed at least 61 lives and injured dozens more.

The collapse, which occurred early Monday morning, has become one of Indonesia's deadliest building disasters in recent years.

By Tuesday afternoon, national disaster officials confirmed that all 61 victims had been recovered from the rubble. Rescue teams, who had worked tirelessly for four days, called off the search late last night after concluding that no more survivors were likely to be found. Among the victims were young students, teachers, and staff members who had been attending morning prayers when the building suddenly crumbled.

Officials reported that 104 people survived the tragedy, with four in critical condition and several others nursing minor injuries. Hospitals in Sidoarjo and nearby Surabaya remain on high alert as they continue to treat the wounded. Two students are still unaccounted for, though authorities now fear they may have perished beneath the debris.

"I thought it was an earthquake," recalled 16-year-old Muhammad Royhan Firdaus, one of the surviving students. "There was a loud crash, then everything went dark. I tried to run, but the ceiling fell on my leg." He was later rescued by emergency workers who pulled him from the wreckage with a broken leg and shoulder injuries.

Another survivor, 13-year-old Selendra Haikal Rakaditya, was found alive after being trapped for nearly three days. "He was weak but still breathing when we reached him," said a member of the rescue team. "We had almost given up hope."

The grief that now grips Sidoarjo is unbearable. Families gathered outside the local police hospital, where white shrouded coffins were lined up for identification. Many parents held photographs of their children, whispering prayers and waiting for confirmation of what they already feared.

"I saw my son alive, and that is enough for me," said Yuni, the mother of Muhammad Royhan. "I will not blame anyone. I believe this was fate." Others, however, have called for justice, demanding investigations into whether poor construction and negligence contributed to the collapse. Local authorities have confirmed that the school's upper floors were built without proper permits, raising questions about oversight and safety compliance.

In a brief statement, Abdus Salam Mujib, the caretaker of the school, apologized to the families and vowed to cooperate with investigators. "This is God's will," he said quietly, "but we must also learn from it."

The tragedy has reignited national debate about building safety standards in Indonesia, where dozens of schools and religious institutions operate with limited supervision. As the nation mourns, the people of Sidoarjo are left with broken hearts, unanswered questions, and a painful reminder of how fragile life can be.
blogs.author: Bridget Muthoni

blogs.title: Gen Z Protests Sweep Across Continents
blogs.body:
A wave of youth-led protests has swept across multiple continents with Gen Z demonstrators challenging governments from Asia to Africa.

In 2024, Kenyan youths protested in Nairobi that quickly spread in other towns and got international coverage. They were against the 2024 Finance Bill which they termed oppressive. 25 June 2024 saw the climax of the protests with protestors vandalizing its parliament leading to deaths of many youths.

Just around the same time, Bangladesh's student movement stormed the Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's residence, forcing her to flee.

This trend has been replicated in other countries across the globe, as a way of seeking political change.

"We are here because we want to hold leaders accountable regardless of where they come from or who they are", said a youth protector in Kenya.

In Nepal the unrest started over a social media ban and grew into a broader anti-corruption protest, with 74 people dying in the demonstrations, including 61 protesters and three police officers, and more than 2,100 injured.

The protests successfully toppled Nepal's Prime Minister, making it one of the most consequential Gen- Z uprisings globally.

Morocco also experienced a grassroot movement calling itself GenZ 212, which organized protests that spread to at least 11 cities, including Casablanca, Rabat, Marrakesh and Agadir, with police arresting nearly 200 people since Saturday.

Demonstrators are demanding reforms to health and education systems, criticizing government spending priorities.

Despite happening 2,000 miles apart, deadly anti-government protests in Nepal and Indonesia share a common denominator: they are being led by Gen Z, those born between 1997 and 2012.

Similar youth-led movements have also occurred in Sri Lanka and Madagascar, suggesting a broader regional trend of youth political mobilization against corruption and systemic issues.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Crisis Intensifies in Italy and Gaza
blogs.body:
The Israel-Gaza war is an ongoing conflict that began when Hamas and other Palestinian militant groups launched a surprise attack on Israel killing at least 71,200 people in Gaza including 69, 236 Palestinians and 1, 983 Israelites.

Similarly, Mali's fuel crisis has caused displacement and economic crisis leading to thousands of deaths and displacement of up to 350,000 people.

Israel responded with a devastating bombing campaign and invaded the Gaza Strip resulting in significant loss of life and displacement.

There has also been significant civilian casualties and infrastructure damage in Gaza as Israel airstrikes and ground operations continue.

In Mali, the Italy's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a travel warning for Mali urging its citizens to leave the country immediately due to a severe fuel shortage and rising security risks.

The warning came after al-Qaeda-linked insurgents Jama'at Nusrat al-Islam imposed a blockade on fuel imports, attacking convoys and causing widespread shortage and price hikes by 500% in the capital city of Bamako.

This has also led to disruption of daily lives, many forced to walk or seek alternative transportation.

The Malian government has also suspended schools and university classes for two weeks due to the reported shortage in fuel.

In International response, the Human Rights reports that German and Italian governments have issued travel advisories warning their citizens against traveling to Mali and recommending that those already in the country leave as soon as possible.

Similarly, the US Embassy in Bamako has also urged American citizens to depart immediately on commercial flights citing risks of terrorist attacks along national highways.

Meanwhile, Russia has agreed to deliver petroleum products to Mali potentially easing the fuel shortage.

While international community is working to find peaceful solutions to the crisis with various countries urging restrain and cooperation in Mali, the UN Secretary-General come out to strongly condemn Israel attacks in Gaza, and the US-brokered ceasefire agreement into effect. However, both sides accuse each other of violations.
blogs.author: Menya K. Silvia

blogs.title: Kenya Gets a Seat On Prestigious FIFA Committees
blogs.body:
Football Kenya Federation (FKF) President Hussein Mohammed has been appointed to the International Federation of Association Football (FIFA) committee.

Hussein will be part of the FIFA Institutional Relations Committee for the 2025-2029 term.

The committee is responsible for building relationships between FIFA, other football bodies, governments and international organisations.

The appointment was confirmed in FIFA's latest announcement, where other officials from across the globe were named to various committees to serve for the next four years.

Hussein will be working alongside football leaders from Brazil, India, Saudi Arabia, Sierra Leone and Austria.

"We will represent Kenya and Africa in the best way possible", said Hussein upon receiving the news of his appointment.

Abdalla Ibrahim, a member of the FKF National Executive Committee was also appointed to the FIFA Stadium and Security Committee.

Additionally, Janet Katisya from Kenya will be joining the FIFA Ethics Committee (Investigatory Chamber), which is responsible for clean and fair football.

"It is a big step for Kenya and for Kenyan football in particular", said Hussein.

These three appointments are a major achievement to Kenya, having recently hosted a successful African Nations Champions alongside Tanzania and Uganda.
blogs.author: Skeeter Imisa

blogs.title: Kenya Focuses On Nurturing Talents at Grassroot Level
blogs.body:
Kenya's renewed focus on grassroots sports development is beginning to pay off, with young athletes across the country recording impressive performances in both local and international competitions.

The progress comes amid increased government and county investment in training facilities, talent scouting and youth sports programs.

According to the Ministry of Sports, over 15 new community stadiums have been upgraded in the past year, while another 30 are under renovation across counties including Nyandarua, Uasin Gishu, and Kisumu. The move aims to decentralize sports infrastructure and nurture talent from the grassroots.

Speaking at the Kenya National Athletics Trials held at the Nyayo National Stadium, Sports Cabinet Secretary Salim mvurya praised the new generation of athletes for their resilience and discipline.

"We are witnessing the rise of a new crop of champions ready to carry Kenya's legacy to the next level. The government remains fully committed to supporting their journey," he said.

Among the standout performers is 18-year-old Faith Cherono from Elegyo Marakwet, who stunned fans by setting a personal best in the 5,000 meters. Cherono, a beneficiary of a county sports scholarship, said the improved training facilities had made a huge difference.

"Before, we struggled to find proper tracks to train on. Now, we have a real chance to compete internationally," she said.

Meanwhile, Kenya's football scene is also experiencing resurgence following reforms initiated by the Football Kenya Federation (FKF) and increased corporate sponsorship.

Clubs such as Gor Mahia and Tusker FC have resumed regional dominance, while the women's league continues to attract new talent and audiences.

Sports analysts say the government's focus on youth empowerment through sports could significantly reduce unemployment and social vices.

"Sports is not just entertainment; it's an economic driver," noted analyst Michael Njoroge, adding that athletics alone contributes billions annually to Kenya's GDP through endorsements, tourism and international events.

As the nation gears up for the 2026 Commonwealth Games, officials believe Kenya's next global champions are already in the making. With continued investment in training, mentorship and sports science, the country hopes to maintain its long-standing reputation as a powerhouse in athletics and beyond.
blogs.author: Ronny Choge

blogs.title: Harambee Stars Receive Boost with Aldrine Kibet's Maiden Call - Up
blogs.body:
The Harambee Stars, Kenya's national football team has received a significant boost with the inclusion of young talent Aldrine Kibet in the squad for the friendlies against Madagascar and Comoros.

Kibet, a 19-year-old attacking midfielder earned his first call-up to the Harambee Stars team early this year. This was upon his impressive performance for St. Anthony's Boys Kitale in the Kenya Secondary Schools Sports Association (KSSSA) which earned him the most valuable player award that court attention of scouts.

The young Kenyan star had been a dependable midfielder at the Eldama Ravine Soccer Center before making His ways to St. Anthony's Boys where his star shined brighter.

Kibet's talent did not go unnoticed, as he later on joined Nastic Academy in Spain before signing a four-year deal with Celta Vigo mid this year, making him one of the most promising Kenyan footballers in Europe.

In Celta Fortuna Vigo, Kibet plays as the club's reserve team as he develops his skills and potentially break into the first team.

Celta Vigo congratulated Kibet upon his inclusion in the Harambee Stars squad saying, "Aldrine Kibet's first call to the senior Kenyan national team. What a moment for our man".

In his naming of a 24-man squad for the then upcoming friendlies against Madagascar and Comoros, Harambee Stars Coach McCarthy featured a mix of experienced players and young talents like Kibet and Baron Ochieng from Zamalek.

Upon his inclusion in squad, Celta Vigo took to social media to congratulate him on his call-up to Harambee Stars. A reaction that showed their confidence in his ability.

Kibet's inclusion in the National team reflects a validation of his hard work and talent as fans eagerly look forward to see him don the national colors.

With the right support and opportunities, Kibet has the potential to become a key player for the national team and make a name for himself in the football world.

blogs.title: Premier League Returns
blogs.body:
The English Premier Leagues officially kicks off today, with teams ready to compete to the highest level for the Premier League title.

The opening game will see defending champions Liverpool hosting AFC Bournemouth with the atmosphere at Anfield expected to be heavy as the club pays tribute to the late Diego Jota.

The opening weekend will feature the biggest game of the weekend at Old Trafford, where hosts Man United will be seeking a chance to shake off the disappointments of last season against their fierce rivals, Arsenal.

On the other hand, Arsenal, will be looking to prove that it has what it takes to finally break through and win the title.

Manchester City, which always seems to be one of the clear favourites, will begin its campaign against Wolverhampton Wanderers, which is known for its ability to cause upsets to other teams with its resilience.

The return of newly promoted Leeds United, Burnley and Sunderland, who have all had busy transfer windows, adds another layer of intrigue. Leeds will start their campaign against Everton, while Burnley and Sunderland will face Tottenham and Westham respectively. Their survival battle will be one of the season's most compelling storylines, a testament to the unforgiving nature of the Premier League.

This season isn't just about the familiar rivalries and the fight for glory; it's also a season of new technologies and innovations. For the first time, the league will use semi-automated offside technology for a full season, a change that promises to bring more consistency to decisions that have long been a source of controversy.

There will also be a few rules added for officiating where a goalkeeper will have a maximum of 8 seconds to hold the ball, otherwise the opposing team will be awarded a corner, together with other set of other rules.

New partnerships with Puma, who will supply matchballs after long-standing partnerships with Nike, also signals a new era.

For the fans, this return is more than just football; it's the return of a new ritual, the joy of gathering with friends, the agony of a last-minute goal conceded, and the ecstasy of a hard-fought victory. It's a journey that will run until the final day on the 24th May, 2026, a journey filled with twists, turns and unforgettable moments and most importantly, banter.
